title: Is it illegal for my employer to honor an out of state (AZ) writ of garnishment if I live in California
question: I'm a victim of identity theft and just found out that my employer got served a writ to garnish my wages from a judgment in Arizona, I've never resided in Arizona and judgment never got domesticated in California. I hired an attorney in Arizona to take care of the default judgment and to lift the garnishment since it was never domesticated, but what can I do in California to get my Money back since up to this date my employer deducted 2400.00 already and they have paid it to the creditors attorney. Isn't my employer liable for Honoring an out of state judgment without checking state law?. Can I file a wage claim with the California labor commissioner?.
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Credit,Debt,Wage garnishment,Bankruptcy and debt,Criminal defense,Criminal charges for theft,Criminal charges for identity theft,Police interrogation,Employment,Employee wages and garnishment,Lawsuits and disputes,State, local, and municipal law,Consumer protection,Default judgment
answers:
Has the lawsuit in Arizona been dismissed? What steps have you taken to prove you are a victim of identity theft. If you've taken the correct steps then you have a reasonable argument to request that the creditor return your money.

If you have never lived in Arizona and someone was using your identity then you should also explore possible debt collection violations.

But, first things first, file a police report, fill out an FTC Identity Theft Affidavit and order your credit reports.

You should probably talk to a lawyer with expertise in employment law. There are several provisions of the California Labor Code which deal with wage garnishments. If the employer violated the law, you are entitled to recover penalties, interest and probably attorney's fees, as well as get your money returned. You can definitely file with the Labor Commissioner, as well as get advise and/or assistance from a lawyer.
